ref.mixed-citation: It belongs to the family of Rubiaceae. The application of this bark against Malarian fevers also met with great interest in Europe. See, for example, Andreas Ottomar Goelicke (1671–1744), praeses; Johann Christoph Möller, respondent. Disputatio inauguralis medica de impostura corticis Peruviani ... Subjicit Joh. Christophorus Möller. Frankfurt an der Oder: Tobias Schwarz. 1727 (10.5962/bhl.title.98775). The bark, which was, as a rule, dried and powdered, contains various alkaloids, particularly quinine and quinidine, that are closely related to the anti-malarial compound quinine. Up to 70 –80% of the total alkaloids contained in the bark are quinine. The bark is a bitter, astringent, tonic herb that lowers fevers, relaxes spasms, is antimalarial (the alkaloid quinine) and slows the heart (the alkaloid quinidine).
